The ordering system is a little tricky when you first go there (you have to mark your order on a card,) but the wait staff is always super personable and happy to help you out, as well as explain what is in some of the more obscure rolls.  I reccommend going during one of their happy hours (my personal favorite being the 9 PM - close) and getting a sake bomb--$5.50 for a huge bottle of Kirin and warm sake. And they don't yell at you if you do the obnoxious but fun pound-on-the-table sake bomb setup. If you are a semi-lightweight like me, that $5.50 will get you a great head start on your night out. During happy hour, you can easily get fed and drunk for about $20 a person, with leftovers to take home.  To be honest, I have only ever ordered sushi rolls and edamame here. All the specialty rolls are delicious and huge--don't be turned off by the price, they pile tons of crunchy and savory extras on top of many of their rolls. The wasabi and ginger are also perfect.  Atmosphere is good. Nice decor, and the music is generally something that suits my taste. Can get a bit loud, but what do you expect from a place that's right next to ASU? My only gripe about this place is that the patio is kind of loud because it faces the intersection, so I never sit out there.

Sushi 101 is a great place to go if you are in the mood for sushi and don't have a lot of money to spend. I have been here a couple of times and usually sit on the left side of the sushi bar. The chefs are very friendly and make really good rolls. The presentation of the rolls are great. Sushi 101 is very Americanized - so if you want to have dinner at a traditional sushi restaurant, this place may not be the best place to go. However, the sushi rolls taste delicious. My waitresses in the past have always been friendly to me. I would have to say though, that rest of the waiters and waitresses in the restuarant were not very professional and the service wasn't the best. On some occasions, my empty water cups did not get refilled at all. Overall, I have always enjoyed my food and would go back but the waiters and waitresses need more training.

I came here not really having much expectations. I just stopped in before going to a comedy show over at Tempe Improv. Thse service was fantastic and the food was great as well. I have only had sushi a few times and the waitress was really helpful and patient when it came to us trying to place an order. I would definitely return

Being that it's downstairs from the Tempe Improv, I eat here a LOT. I usually get there during happy hour, which is really great if you love sushi and need to have at least 4 different kinds in front of you.  The staff is always friendly (and cute!) and ready to answer any questions about the menu. Our drinks were constantly filled throughout the meal, too. Everything came out pretty quickly (we waited less than ten minutes for food). It's Americanized sushi. Anyone who sees "bar and grill" should know that and not expect to be blown away. It's great food. It's fresh. There's a great variety. It's not Jiro making it.

i cannot get enough of this place!  the sushi is sooo good and the happy hour prices are insane! The heart attack roll and krazy maki are unique and sooo tasty.  The shirts the employees where are cute "miso hungry"  Give this place a try with happy hour everyday! see ya there :)

This is an update to a really bad review I wrote a few years ago. I live near sushi 101 now and I have been here a couple of times for happy hour. Sushi is hit or miss. I think that with the happy hour prices you can get a pretty good deal on lunch. Their salmon nigiri is also really good (sometimes!) Just wanted to update my review since I think Sushi 101 deserves more stars than I initially gave.
The food is kind of ok, but the price is too high. Suggest to go on Sunday with "all can eat" which is limit 1 hour for 25/person.

NEVER AGAIN! My bestie Monica just wrote a review but I must say something about this place! I left very unhappy. Liz, our waitress needs to chill and wait until the customers is ready to pay!! She kept coming over and over again to collect the check and we weren't even ready to hand it to her. She ignored us the whole time we were there but was quick to get that check paid. I felt so uncomfortable. The manager was awesome though but still not enough to get me back in that place. On to the next...

Service at the bar was inattentive, our Edamame never showed up, sashimi was meh.  Beer was cold and good.  Biggest problem was the disgusting restroom.  For the novices out there, if the bathroom is dirty then be worried about the cleanliness of the kitchen.  If you can't take care of a public space for your customers then why would you take care of the place where food is prepared.  Will update if we get sick.

Their happy hour prices were decent, and the setting is nice. Sushi rolls were good, but just be aware when a roll says "crunch" roll, there's barely anything on there. We thought they gave us a normal Cali roll until we looked really close and noticed it was dusted with very tiny tempura flakes. Not what I expected, but still good food, just not really crunch rolls.

I like (don't love) sushi 101 for location and convenience. It beats out the nearby RA in the accessibility column since you don't have to deal with parking on Mill.   101 has a good happy hour and a solid selection of rolls to choose from. It's not too expensive but you get what you pay for. I find it to be somewhat bland at times.   That being said, it's perfect for the college aged to get together with a group friends for some affordable sushi. You can't beat that location if you are living near/on ASU campus.     Go Devils

This place was a shocker. I suppose by now I have a certain level of expectation from mid-continental sushi and I'm ok with the quality in AZ despite the distance from aquatic life (Tempe Town Lake doesn't count). While my bar here isn't high, this place wasn't on my list of places to check out. Sushi 101 was a very pleasant surprise. Their menu is diverse enough to appeal to those that like crap in their rolls i.e. cream cheese, those that like the classics, and those that are willing to explore some kind of happiness in between - me.  First of all, I was so impressed that they have more than 1 boring veggie roll. Who on earth offers 4 veggie rolls? This pleases me so. I was even more excited that one of them comes with jalapenos on top - yum! Secondly, the Sun Devil Roll is edible bliss and makes me wish I could carry around that spicy taste in my mouth for days.  I've only ordered take-out so I can't really speak to the atmosphere, but I love sushi so much that the environment I eat it in doesn't matter compared to the taste. The people that work there are pretty cool and it's about 2 miles away from home. Is this the BEST sushi in AZ? Is it the cheapest? No and no. But tasty and convenient enough to make the speed dial.

I first came to Sushi 101 as a wide-eyed freshmen at ASU and have been back plenty of times since.  This is pretty much a staple place for all ASU students to go to since it's right across the street from campus.  Anyways, on with the review!  The decor and ambiance of the place is pretty chill.  The place is always busy and service is usually speedy.  Try the stuffed jalapenos; wash it down with lots of eel and salmon; get some different bites of tuna in between; order the obligatory ASU and Sun Devil Rolls; never EVER forget the soft shell crab; and once you've discreetly unbuttoned the top button of your skinny jeans and kicked your feet up into your friend's lap, splurge and get some tempura ice cream because let's face it:  There's always room for fried dessert.  While the quality isn't exactly the best and I wouldn't drive out of my way to stop in for a bite, I'll always have a soft spot for Sushi 101 and all the warm fuzzy [and drunken] memories attached to the place.    Also, they have a great Happy Hour menu worth checking out and their lunch specials are decent.
This place has a great happy hour. The  drinks and rolls are very inexpensive and are pretty good.

Easy to find. Ample parking. I can say that much about this place.   For me, it's not anything to write home about. In fact, why bother? Well, perhaps you want a pretty central area to meet friends for lunch or after work. Or maybe it's the middle of the weekend and your jonesin' for sushi. Then, go. But otherwise, don't. I mean, really, with a name like Sushi 101, you can expect it to cater to ASU kids and residents down the block. Hey, no biggie, right?  If I were you, I wouldn't bother, though.  Service is good, although during a lunch visit once, I felt almost hurried out the door when all I really wanted was to enjoy my hour break, settle back into the booth and savor each bite. Seems that was too much to ask, for the check came long before 1/2 my roll was eaten. To me, that reeks worse than rotten fish.
I have been going to this place for years now! They have the best sushi around. I would definitely recommend to someone wanted to find a good sushi restaurant!!!

Best happy hour sushi prices I've seen.  They have happy hour that ends at 7pm, and then again starting at 9pm.  Sushi is very good. Never been sick here from it.   Been here over many years, would like to go more often but hard to find people.  Servers are often really good here.

Garrison is an absolute gentlemen and a very kind host.  Him and his staff are friendly, polite and very accommodating.  Last few times I've been there, Colton has been my server; words can't describe how incredibly exquisite his skills are as a very impressive server.  Not only does he bring a bright smile but also friendly and very superb personality with top-notch service that words simply cannot describe.  I highly recommend stopping by; let Colton suggest his favorite drink and appetizers, he always gets it just right.

I always go during happy hour (which they have every day) and the prices on rolls are pretty good, cheaper than other places I've been (Sushi Eye, Pan Asia etc). The yellowtail sashimi is good and I've liked all the rolls I've tried there except the baked salmon roll (which my husband loves) I usually get a philly roll, golden gate roll and the calimari roll. I won't say it's the best sushi I've ever had, but it's certainly not the worst.    The service is usually sub-par. ASU students who don't really care whether you've been waiting 15 min for a refill, but what can you expect?  Overall I would say it's worth it as long as you go during happy hour!

Food:  The grizzly roll was excellent and the garlic edamame was spicy and delicious.  The waitress brought out miso soup, wasabi and ginger right away.  If their other rolls are as good as this one, then there are about 5 or 6 more that I need to try.  Service:  No complaints.  The lady at front was super nice, the chef and I chatted a bit and the servers were attentive.  Perhaps it was because I went in the afternoon and not the busy time...?  Atmosphere:  A little dark, but it has the whole Japanese feel to it right down to the Lucky Cat at the bar.  Did not check the bathrooms...  Price:  Mid-range for a sushi joint.  It is also close to a college, so I am surprised that they do so well given that sushi is usually a more expensive meal for college kids.  Maybe they are all rich...  Overall:  If I am ever back in Tempe, I will stop by again.  Would love to try more and I am happy to see a good sushi place in the middle of the desert!

One of my favorite places to eat in Tempe and absolutely my favorite sushi place here. The Cheetah roll is my favorite and, of course, the happy hour is fantastic. I can even get my friends and family who don't eat fish to come with me because of the happy hour.

We come here on Mondays all the time because they have saki bombs all night for $3.75 if you sit at the bar.  The service is always awesome. Chelsea is always super nice. Food is fast and cheap on happy hour.

Congratulations Sushi 101.  You are my first one star review.  I have high standards for this category and you get to go down in my Yelp history as breaking my 1 star cherry.   This is the WORST sushi I have ever had.  I would rather eat the stuff from Kyoto Bowl.  In fact, in comparison Kyoto bowl sounds rather delicious to me at the moment, that is if you didn't turn me off from sushi altogether.   Happy hour schmappy hour, I can't believe people pay to eat this crap.    On top of that the service was awful.  I had a beer and finished it not half way into my time there and was never asked if I wanted another.   After that I find on my bill they factored gratuity into my tip.  The only time I know this to be a common practice is for groups of 6 or more. There were five of us.  I think they have to build in the tip because they know they are awful and wouldn't make any money otherwise.  College kids, I know you don't have much money but trust me, there are plenty of decent or even great sushi places out there that offer amazing HH deals.   I cringe to think of how many kids will have their first sushi experience here and will never know how truly delicious and amazing sushi actually is.

Sushi 101! Back on the east coast, this was one of my fave sushi spots to hit. I found this one after a brutal MBA exam recently...I'd had nothing to eat all day (bad idea when you have a three-hour exam) and the Yelp app asked me if I wanted to check in at Sushi 101. Why, oh my goodness, I'd LOVE to check in at Sushi 101!   This was around 4 p.m. on Friday, and the place had a fair number of people in it for that time of day, although it wasn't crowded. Since I was alone the hostess seated me at the bar (which I love in a sushi restaurant). I chose the Monkey Brains and the Krazy Maki rolls. That's A LOT of sushi, m' friends. But I ate all of it (remember, I was dumb enough to take a grad school exam on an empty stomach).   Both of these happened to be deep fried, but they had cream cheese--which is my weakness when it comes to sushi. I would have liked to see more sushi rolls with cream cheese, but my guess is that could be added to any roll.   They have a regular menu which features appetizers, bento specials, soups and salads, other entrees, and noodles. But it's sushi for this chick...   This location is in the group of stores on the NEC of Rural and University Dr in Tempe, just south of the 202. The bar seating is nice. Check the board on the wall for daily specials, and hey--they also offer sushi-making classes!   Bonus: The receipts give you the tip calculations automatically, and they also say "May the force be with you." I'm a fan!

today I ordered pento box and they gave me DEEP FRIED SALMON!!, no grill as menu says, CORN!, yes corn in a Japanese dish, "salad", only very unexpensive lettuce and couple of gross veggies. Service, terrible and quality of food, grose, no to mention the smell in the restaurante. NEVER AGAIN!!!!!!
Cool atmosphere with an excellent happy hour menu covering both sushi and appetizers.
